Scientist II – Claustrum & Correlates of Consciousness

The Allen Institute seeks to understand the relationship between conscious perception in the mouse and neural activity in cortex and the closely associated claustrum. We are seeking a Scientist II, reporting to Shawn Olsen and Christof Koch, who will head a small research team investigating the in vivo activity and behavioral functions of the claustrum, a deep brain structure with extensive connections to the cortex.

The claustrum is implicated in cognitive processes such as selective attention and in conscious and multi-modal perception. The project goal is to record and perturb claustrum activity in the context of a visual choice task using Neuropixels and/or multi-photon calcium imaging in transgenic animals, in combination with modern perturbation techniques (primarily optogenetics, secondarily DREADDS, electrical stimulation).

This project will require the individual to perform surgeries, train mice to perform behavioral tasks, perform neural recording and optogenetic perturbation experiments, analyze and publish the resulting data. As a Scientist II, this individual will lead and motivate others. Overall, we seek an experienced neuroscientist with a passion for understanding the neural correlates of consciousness.

Job Responsibilities
  • Train mice in a variety of visual behavioral tasks using custom hardware and software.
  • Develop and maintain custom software for neural and behavioral data collection and analysis.
  • Carry out large-scale electrophysiological recording experiments (Neuropixels) and optogenetics, possibly complemented by in-vivo calcium imaging.
  • Analyze and visualize in vivo datasets and collaborate with computational scientists on the team.
  • Present progress to research community internally at the Institute and to the external community. Scientist may also write associated manuscripts.
  • Lead a small group of scientists and associated staff.


Required Qualifications
  • PhD degree in Neuroscience, Biology, or related field.
  • Strong programming skills for experimental control and data analysis.
  • Experience working with live rodents.


Preferred Qualifications
  • Experience with rodent behavior training.
  • Good written and verbal communication skills.
  • Ability to meet timelines and deliverables in a collaborative environment.
  • Strong publication record.
  • At least 2 years postdoctoral experience.
  • Python programming experience preferred (Matlab also useful).
  • Experience with calcium imaging and/or extracellular electrophysiology, and/or in-vivo optogenetics.
  • Rodent stereotactic surgery experience.
  • Proven independent thinking and flexibility.
  • Experience in pursuing research projects in collaborative fashion and in working with other scientists, students and staff.

It is the policy of the Allen Institute to provide equal employment opportunity (EEO) to all persons regardless of age, color, national origin, citizenship status, physical or mental disability, race, religion, creed, gender, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity and/or expression, genetic information, marital status, status with regard to public assistance, veteran status, or any other characteristic protected by federal, state or local law. In addition, the Allen Institute will provide reasonable accommodations for qualified individuals with disabilities.
